Graphical abstract Highlights ► CMK-3 carbon replica exhibits high catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of propane. ► Reaction temperature and feed composition strongly influence catalytic performance. ► Changes in surface composition are observed during the catalytic process. ► Oxygen-containing groups play a crucial role in the propane conversion. CMK-3 carbon replica was synthesized by carbonization of sucrose introduced to the pore system of a SBA-15 hard template followed by dissolving SiO2 with HF. The material with a stable hexagonal structure and an expanded surface area (S BET =1287m2/g) was obtained. TG measurements showed that CMK-3 type mesoporous carbon started to be intensively oxidized by molecular O2 above 723K. This carbon sample was tested as a catalyst of dehydrogenation of propane to propene under oxidative (O2:C3H8 =0.25, 0.50 and 1.00) and non-oxidative (O2:C3H8 =0.00) conditions in the temperature range from 573 to 873K. The propene yield increased with rise in the reaction temperature, however above 573K the formation of side-products (C2H6, C2H4, CH4 and H2) was observed. Moreover, coke was deposited on the catalyst surface. A decrease in the mass of a catalyst bed after the catalytic runs suggested the participation of oxygen in burning of deposited and bulk coke. The surface composition of a spent catalyst was investigated by XPS and TPD analysis. The changes in the concentration of oxygen functional groups, caused by the catalytic reaction, were observed regardless of a reaction temperature and feed composition. Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation Propene Carbon replica CMK-3 1 Introduction Carbons with the surface exhibiting various electronic properties can act as catalysts of the processes occurring in the presence of metal conductors (e.g. hydrogenation), semiconductors (e.g. oxidation) and insulators (e.g. polymerization or halogenation) [1]. Exclusive catalytic activity of carbons can be enhanced by the controlled formation of their mesoporosity and nanosized particles. Ordered mesoporous carbons (OMCs), carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and carbon nanofibers (CNFs) have high surface area with a large number of sites, which are active in various catalytic processes. In 1999, Ryoo et al. [2] described a pioneer synthesis of highly ordered mesoporous carbon (CMK-1) belonging to a wide group of materials designated as CMK-n (Carbon Mesostructured by KAIST [3]). Nevertheless, CMK-3 developed by Jun et al. [4] has been the most intensively studied. This material is prepared using SBA-15 mesoporous silica as a hard template and therefore shows the highly-ordered hexagonal arrangement of carbon rods interconnected by carbon bridges (p6mm symmetry) [5]. The typical synthesis of a carbon replica includes: (1) preparation of mesoporous silica; (2) deposition of a carbon source (e.g. sucrose, poly(furfuryl alcohol), polyacrylonitrile, benzene, propylene, acenaphthene) in the channels of a hard template by impregnation or chemical vapor deposition; (3) carbonization of an organic precursor in the obtained composite; (4) removal of the silica template with a NaOH or HF solution [6,7]. The final material is characterized by high specific surface area, well defined size of pores and particular surface composition, which make it useful in industrial applications including adsorption and catalysis. Carbon replicas have been successfully used in cellulose hydrolysis [8], sorption of dyes [9], hydrogen storage [10] and as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries [11]. They have been also examined as promising catalysts in the conversion of saturated hydrocarbons into their unsaturated analogs, which are valuable feedstock in chemical industry [12]. Propene is one of the most important intermediates and monomers in different petrochemical and polymer processes. Nowadays, steam cracking, catalytic cracking and selective technologies like dehydrogenation of propane, metathesis and methanol based processes (MTO or MTP) are the primary propene sources. However, a strong demand for propene leads to the optimization of the commercial technology as well as to a growing interest in developing new processes for the C3H6 production. Selective oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene in the presence of various hydrogen acceptors (e.g. O2, N2O or CO2) has been the subject of investigations for many years [13–17]. Among proposed solutions the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane with oxygen is the most extensively studied. In contrast to the nonoxidative pathway of propene obtaining, ODH of propane has no thermodynamic limitations and is a highly exothermic reaction. However, in this process there are still unsolved engineering and technological problems, such as heat transfer and flammability of an oxygen–hydrocarbon mixture. The key issue is also the control of high selectivity at a reasonable conversion per-pass. In commercial nonoxidative dehydrogenation of propane, 40% conversion at selectivity above 80–90% is achieved [18], while in the case of ODH similar selectivity is usually obtained when the conversion of propane per-pass is 10–15% [19]. Therefore, developing a selective catalyst for this process is still a great challenge. Pure carbonaceous materials like nanofilaments, OMCs and onion-like carbons (OLC) have been recently examined as promising catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons [20–22]. Su et al. [23] reported high catalytic activity and selectivity of the CMK-3 carbon in ethylbenzene ODH used to the styrene production. At 673K the ethylbenzene conversion of 69%, at the styrene selectivity of 76%, was achieved. It was suggested that the oxygen containing functional groups present on the carbon surface are responsible for high catalytic activity. Liu et al. [24] revealed that OMCs exhibit an excellent catalytic performance also in nonoxidative dehydrogenation of propane. In the present work we have investigated the catalytic performance of CMK-3 type carbon replica in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. The influence of a reaction temperature and feed composition on the activity and selectivity of the studied carbon catalyst is discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of CMK-3 carbon replica SBA-15 was synthesized under acidic conditions using Pluronic P123 triblock copolymer (EO20PO70EO20, M av =5800, supplied by Aldrich) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica source according to the procedure described elsewhere [25]. In a polypropylene bottle, 8g of Pluronic P123 was dissolved in a solution containing 60g of distilled water and 120g of 2M HCl at 308K. The mixture was vigorously stirred until the complete dissolution of the polymeric surfactant. Subsequently, 17g of TEOS (98%, Aldrich) was added dropwise to the solution under vigorous stirring (400rpm) at 308K. Finally, the mixture was stirred (400rpm) for another 20h at 308K and then hydrothermally treated under static conditions for 24h at 363K. The obtained white precipitate was filtered without washing, dried overnight at 333K and calcined in air by rising temperature from ambient to 823K over 9h period and an isothermal step at 823K for further 12h. The prepared SBA-15 material was used as a hard template to the synthesis of a CMK-3 replica [4]. Mesoporous silica (1g) was impregnated with a solution containing 5g of water, 1.25g of sucrose and 0.14g of sulfuric acid. The sample was dried in two steps: at 373K for 6h and then at 433K for further 6h. The sample of SBA-15 containing partially polymerized and carbonized sucrose was impregnated again. In the second impregnation, a solution with 0.8g of sucrose and 0.09g of sulfuric acid dissolved in 3g of water was used. The drying procedure was repeated. Carbonization was completed by rising temperature (1Kmin−1) up to 1073K in flowing N2 and an isothermal step at 1073K for further 12h. The carbon-silica composite obtained after pyrolysis was washed two times in 10% hydrofluoric acid solution at room temperature to remove the silica template. The final material was washed three times with deionized water (3×150cm3 per 1g of a composite) and dried at 393K for 10h. 2.2 Characterization methods Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 77K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Specific surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method within the relative pressure p/p 0 =0.05–0.15. Pore size distributions were determined from the adsorption branch using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method taking into account the corrected form of the Kelvin equation proposed by Kruk et al. [26]. Total pore volumes were obtained from the amounts of nitrogen adsorbed at p/p 0 =0.95 or vicinity. The structure of materials was studied by X-ray diffraction using a Bruker D2 Phaser instrument. The diffraction patterns were collected with CuKα radiation λ =1.54184Å in the range of 2θ from 0.5 to 10.0° with a 0.004° step. The thermal stability of CMK-3 was examined with a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments) thermoanalyzer. The measurement was performed in an alumina pan using about 4.4mg of the sample in air atmosphere (a flow rate of 100ml/min) from 298 to 1273K at a heating rate of 20Kmin−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were measured on a Prevac photoelectron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical VG SCIENTA R3000 analyzer. The photoelectron spectra were measured using a monochromatized aluminum AlKα source (E =1486.6eV). No additional charge compensation was applied. For calibration of the binding energy scale, the Au 4f7/2 signal at 84.0eV of a clean Au surface was used. The base pressure in the analysis chamber during the measurements was 5×10−9 mbar. Spectra were recorded with constant pass energy of 100eV for the survey and for high resolution spectra. The composition and chemical surrounding of the sample surface were investigated on the basis of the areas and binding energies of C 1s and O 1s photoelectron peaks. The fitting of high resolution spectra was provided through the CasaXPS software. Temperature-programmed desorption experiments (TPD) were performed in a system consisted of a quartz microreactor, a well-controlled tubular furnace and a gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A 100mg sample of fresh or used CMK-3 was preheated in He for 2h at 373K and subsequently a TPD measurement was carried out by heating the sample from 373K to 1073K at 10Kmin−1 in helium stream (30cm3 min−1). 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were carried out in a flow-type quartz reactor packed with 200mg of the catalyst (grain size 0.2–0.3mm, without dilution). The feed was composed of gas mixture of O2:C3H8:He=0.5:2.0:27.5, 1.0:2.0:27.0, 2.0:2.0:26.0 or C3H8:He=2.0:28.0 (molar ratio). In all cases the total flow rate was 30cm3 min−1. Before the catalytic tests, the samples were pretreated in flowing dry He (30cm3 min−1) for 0.5h at a reaction temperature. The catalytic runs were carried out at 573, 673, 723, 773 and 873K under atmospheric pressure. The reactants and products were analyzed on-line using an Agilent 6890N gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with two columns (Hayesep Q and molecular sieve 5A) and a thermal conductivity detector. The column packed with Hayesep Q was used for the separation of H2, CO2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, and C3H8, while CH4 and CO were analyzed using molecular sieve 5A. The hot spot effect was excluded by the independent experiments using the dilution of catalyst with SiC. Conversion of propane (X p) and oxygen (X ox), yield of propene (Y p) and selectivity to products (S i) were calculated as described below: X p = n C 3 H 8 , inlet − n C 3 H 8 , outlet n C 3 H 8 , inlet × 100 % X ox = n O 2 , inlet − n O 2 , outlet n O 2 , inlet × 100 % Y p = n C 3 H 6 , outlet n C 3 H 8 , inlet × 100 % S i = a i 3 ⋅ n i × 100 % n C 3 H 8 , inlet − n C 3 H 8 , outlet where: n C 3 H 8 , inlet , n O 2 , inlet and n C 3 H 8 , outlet , n O 2 , outlet are numbers of propane or oxygen moles in inlet and outlet of reactor, respectively; n C 3 H 6 , outlet is a number of propene moles in outlet; a i is a number of carbon atoms in a product, and n i is a number of moles of a product. The number of propane moles converted to CO and CO2 ( n C O x ) was calculated assuming the balance of carbon in outlet ( n C , outlet ) and inlet ( n C , inlet ) of reactor. n CO x = n CO x ,outlet − ( n C , outlet − n C , inlet ) Loss of catalyst bed mass (m bed) during the ODH process carried out at 573, 673, 723, 773 and 873K at the stoichiometric feed composition (O2:C3H8:He=1.0:2.0:27.0) was calculated according to the formula: m bed = m c , before − m c , after m c , before × 100 % where: m c , before and m c , after are masses of the CMK-3 catalyst before and after 4h time-on-stream, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and thermal stability of CMK-3 replica Fig. 1A shows the small-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of the hard silica template (SBA-15) and the corresponding carbon sample. They exhibit a sharp peak at low angle and two significantly less intense peaks at higher angles corresponding to the (100), (110) and (200) diffractions of the hexagonal space group p6mm. This ordered structure indicates that the final material is a replica of SBA-15 type silica used as a hard template. The a 0 unit cell parameter of CMK-3, calculated according to the formula a 0 = 2 d 110 / 3 , was equal to 9.2nm. The N2 adsorption isotherms recorded for SBA-15 and CMK-3 (presented in Fig. 1B) of type IV are characteristic of mesoporous solids. The synthesized carbon replica had a high surface area (S BET =1287m2/g), a large pore volume (V total =1.22cm3/g) and a narrow pore size distribution between 2 and 10nm (inset to Fig. 1B). The thermal stability of the synthesized CMK-3 replica was evaluated by the thermogravimetric method. In Fig. 2 the TG curve measured in the air-flow along with the differential signal (DTG) are shown. The carbon material was resistant to burning up to about 723K. The further temperature increase resulted in intensification of the exothermic oxidation process, which reached maximum rate at 848K. Burning of carbon was finished about 913K. The remaining mass related to ash was 4.4wt.%. 3.2 Effect of reaction temperature on catalytic activity of CMK-3 in ODH of propane The synthesized CMK-3 was tested as a catalyst in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane at different temperatures. The collected results are summarized in Table 1 . Propene, carbon oxides and water (not analyzed quantitatively) were the main products at all the studied temperatures. Above 573K light hydrocarbons, such as methane, ethane and ethene, were formed as byproducts. Small amounts of hydrogen were additionally detected among the reaction products at 773 and 873K. The increase in the propane conversion and the propene yield as well as the drop in selectivity toward propene were observed with rise in the reaction temperature. Fig. 3A and B illustrates the variation of propane conversion and selectivity to propene with time on stream (TOS). At the highest temperature the conversion of propane gradually decreased, while below 873K the deactivation was relatively slow. This suggests that the CMK-3 replica was highly stable under the reaction conditions. Such a conclusion is supported by powder X-ray diffraction patterns and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms measured for the spent catalyst (shown in Supporting data: Fig. S1 and S2 as well as Table S1). No clear changes in the sample structure were found. Only the decrease in the pore size from 3.6nm (for fresh CMK-3) to 2.8–2.9nm (for used CMK-3 regardless of the reaction temperature) was observed. BET surface areas and total pore volumes of the spent catalysts were close to those characteristic of the fresh sample excluding the material after the reaction at 873K, which lost significantly porosity due to intensive burning. Similar high stability of CMK-3 was reported previously in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene at 673K [23]. The influence of the reaction temperature on the ratio of carbon atoms in the reactor outlet to that in inlet (Coutlet/Cinlet) after 4h on stream and the loss of catalyst mass (m bed) is presented in Fig. 4 . During the ODH process two inverse reactions can have significant impact on the mass of catalyst bed: (i) coke formation leading to an increase in catalyst mass and (ii) burning of carbon (both bulk and surface) resulting in a mass loss. The ratio of Coutlet/Cinlet above 1, indicating that the number of C atoms in outlet is slightly higher than in inlet, and the positive m bed prove that burning of CMK-3 is a predominant effect in the studied reaction system. However, the Coutlet/Cinlet and m bed values vary with the reaction temperature. At temperatures below 773K the increase in the m bed value, caused by the intense catalyst burning, is observed. At higher temperatures the value of m bed decreases. This can be explained if we consider the above results with respect to conversion of oxygen. The GC results indicate that at stoichiometric feed composition 100% oxygen conversion was obtained at 723K. This means that at and above this temperature m bed and the ratio of Coutlet/Cinlet are strongly controlled by coke deposition. Since high temperature accelerates the coke formation, both the catalyst mass loss and the ratio of Coutlet/Cinlet decrease with raising temperature due to the deficiency of oxygen in the reaction zone. The surface composition of the fresh and spent catalyst was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The survey spectra (not shown) revealed that carbon was dominant element present on the CMK-3 surface. However, a relatively high amount of oxygen functional groups was identified on the outermost atomic layers. The O 1s XPS spectra of fresh CMK-3 and the carbon replica after catalytic runs at various temperatures are demonstrated in Fig. 5 . Four different forms of surface oxygen can be distinguished: (i) carbonyl oxygen atoms in CO groups with binding energy of 530.6–531.3eV; (ii) oxygen atoms in hydroxyl groups COH with binding energy of 532.9–533.6eV; (iii) oxygen atoms in adsorbed water (536.0–536.4eV) and (iv) chemisorbed oxygen (538.0–539.4eV) [27,28]. The presence of these groups was also confirmed by C 1s core level spectra (high resolution C 1s spectra not shown here). The C 1s spectra were deconvoluted into four individual peaks. The main, dominating one with binding energy of 284.5–284.6eV and an asymmetric shape was attributed to CC sp2 and CC sp3 carbons in graphitic and disordered carbon species, respectively [27,29]. On the basis of the literature data [28,30,31] the additional two signals were assigned to carbon atoms associated with oxygen. The component peak at 286.4–286.7eV corresponded to carbon atoms in COH groups, whereas the peak at 287.5–288.0eV to carbon in CO groups. The signal at 290.0–290.3eV was assigned to shake-up satellite due to π–π* transitions in aromatic rings. The content of various surface forms of oxygen and carbon calculated basing on the XPS results is presented in Table 2 . It was found that for the CMK-3 catalyst after the catalytic tests at 573 and 673K the concentration of oxygen functional groups was higher compared to the fresh sample. This effect can be explained by the formation of strongly oxidized carbonaceous deposit, which is also observed after the run at 723K. Nevertheless, the increase in the reaction temperature to 773K resulted in a significant decrease in the amount of surface oxygen. Fig. 6 displays the TPD profiles of fresh and used CMK-3 – after the ODH process at 573, 673, 723, 773 and 873K. It is considered that different oxygen containing functional groups existing on the surface of carbon materials decompose at various temperature, i.e. carboxylic acids – below 700K, anhydrides and lactones between 700 and 900K, while ethers, phenols and carbonyls/quinones above 900K [24,32,33]. All TPD profiles of used CMK-3 exhibit one intensive peak with the maximum at 925K (excluding the sample after the ODH process at 873K) and a high temperature shoulder at about 1080K, which may originate from ethers, phenols and carbonyls/quinones decomposition. More precisely, in the case of ordered mesoporous carbon materials the band at 925K was assigned to decomposition of phenols, while the high temperature maximum to carbonyls/quinones [24]. In the case of fresh CMK-3 an additional low temperature desorption peak appears confirming the presence of carboxylic groups. Furthermore, a comparison of intensity of the bands at 925 and 1080K for used CMK-3 reveals that the surface concentration of oxygen containing functional groups increases with temperature up to 673K and then decreases with further raising temperature. Similar correlation can be found by XPS (Fig. 5). However, the XPS results are not directly comparable with other techniques because only uppermost layers are investigated by this method. Nevertheless, XPS and TPD confirm that at high temperatures when the catalyst exhibits the high activity the concentration of functional groups is lower. This indicates that in the presence of strong oxidant (oxygen) and reductants (propane/hydrogen) the surface of CMK-3 is firstly oxidized. This process is the most intensive from 573 to 673K. Above this temperature range reduction/decomposition processes dominate. The contribution of latter mentioned processes increases with temperature, therefore the concentration of oxygen functional groups on the surface of used CMK-3 is much lower after the ODH process carried out at high temperatures. The catalytic activity of carbonaceous materials in the ODH processes is usually attributed to the presence of oxygen functional groups [20,23,34,35]. According to one of the accepted reaction mechanism, dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons occurs on strongly basic carbonyl groups, for example quinone-type, which are transformed into the surface hydroxyl groups. In a subsequent step, oxygen chemisorbed on basal planes of the graphite layers diffuses to hydroxyl groups and oxidizes them with a release of water molecule [20,23]. Our XPS and TPD results indicate that both carbonyl and hydroxyl species coexist on the surface of fresh and used CMK-3 (Table 2). These groups, which are formed during CMK-3 synthesis and process in the presence of oxygen, are involved in the above mentioned redox cycle similar as in the ODH of ethylbenzene and n-butane. The oxygen containing groups may also participate in nonoxidative dehydrogenation of propane. According to Liu et al. [24] on carbonyl/quinone groups (CO), which act as electron donors, molecule of propene is produced and hydroxyl groups (COH) remain as intermediates. In the next step, the hydroxyl groups decompose (2COH→2CO+H2) forming re-oxidized carbonyl species and gaseous hydrogen. This thermal decomposition step is favored at high temperatures. In order to estimate the contribution of nonoxidative and oxidative pathways of propene formation, the ODH process was periodically carried out with and without oxygen. Fig. 7A displays the variation of propene yield as a function of time-on-stream. At all studied temperatures the yield of propene is higher in the process carried out in the presence of oxygen. In the temperature range 573–723K the relative difference between propene yield obtained in the presence and absence of O2 (R parameter) is above 60%, confirming the high contribution of oxidative pathway in the propene formation (Fig. 7B). In a contrast, above 723K the R value decreases dramatically. For example, at 873K the yield of propene is only 17% higher in the process carried out in the presence of O2. This clearly indicates that at high temperature the contribution of nonoxidative pathway of propene formation is significant. 3.3 Effect of feed composition on catalytic activity of CMK-3 in ODH of propane The catalytic activity of the CMK-3 replica was examined at an optimal temperature of 723K with varying feed gas composition (Fig. 8 ). The measurements were performed using the feed without O2 (O2:C3H8 =0.00) as well as at the O2:C3H8 molar ratio ranging from 0.25 to 1.00. CMK-3 exhibited poor activity under nonoxidative conditions. In the absence of O2 the conversion of propane after 4h-on-stream did not exceed 3%, which is in agreement with the results reported in Fig. 7. It is also clear from Fig. 8A that the conversion of propane was enhanced steeply in the presence of oxygen, and the increase in the reaction rate is correlated with the feed composition. Unfortunately, in parallel to the raise of the propane conversion, the selectivity to propene dropped. Finally, the effect of feed gas composition on the catalyst stability was studied (Fig. 8B). In the absence of O2, the propene yield slightly decreased in the initial period of reaction reaching the stable level after the short induction time. In a contrast, under oxidative conditions the decrease in the yield of propene was observed during the whole ODH process. This constant loss of catalytic activity was probably caused by a gradual burning of the catalyst in the presence of O2. Nevertheless, no significant destruction in the structure and texture of the CMK-3 catalyst was found after 4h time-on-stream at different feed compositions (cf. Supporting data: Fig. S3 and S4 as well as Table S2). Only in the reaction performed at the highest O2:C3H8 molar ratio porosity of the catalyst decreased significantly. On the other hand, the influence of oxygen content on the pore size of CMK-3 can be found. The increase in O2:C3H8 molar ratio resulted in the limitation of pore size. This effect can be attributed to the burning of carbon bridges linking more stable carbon rods present in the CMK-3 catalyst. The reaction conditions had a crucial influence on the concentration of oxygen functional groups on the surface, as was determined by XPS. The results of surface analysis performed for the samples before and after the catalytic runs are summarized in Fig. 9 and Table 3 . During the process carried out without oxygen in the reaction system, a removal of oxygen-containing species was noted. On the other hand, the introduction of oxidizing agent resulted in the raise of the number of oxygen atoms bound to the surface. This beneficial effect was found only for the O2 content below and equal to stoichiometric O2/C3H8 ratio. The excess of oxygen promoted burning of carbon replica and the concentration of oxygen functional groups decreased considerably during the ODH process. 4 Conclusion Mesoporous carbon CMK-3 was applied as a new catalyst for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene. The variations of catalytic performance and the concentration of surface oxygen containing groups with temperature and feed gas composition were investigated. The catalytic studies revealed that pure CMK-3 exhibits high activity, selectivity and good stability in the studied process. At 723K stable propene yield higher than 11% at selectivity above 55% within 4h time-on-stream was achieved. XPS and TPD experiments showed the presence of hydroxyl and carbonyl groups on the surface of the fresh and used CMK-3 catalyst, which are considered to be responsible for the catalytic activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. coredata.dc:description: CMK-3 carbon replica was synthesized by carbonization of sucrose introduced to the pore system of a SBA-15 hard template followed by dissolving SiO2 with HF. The material with a stable hexagonal structure and an expanded surface area (S BET =1287m2/g) was obtained. TG measurements showed that CMK-3 type mesoporous carbon started to be intensively oxidized by molecular O2 above 723K. This carbon sample was tested as a catalyst of dehydrogenation of propane to propene under oxidative (O2:C3H8 =0.25, 0.50 and 1.00) and non-oxidative (O2:C3H8 =0.00) conditions in the temperature range from 573 to 873K. The propene yield increased with rise in the reaction temperature, however above 573K the formation of side-products (C2H6, C2H4, CH4 and H2) was observed. Moreover, coke was deposited on the catalyst surface. A decrease in the mass of a catalyst bed after the catalytic runs suggested the participation of oxygen in burning of deposited and bulk coke. The surface composition of a spent catalyst was investigated by XPS and TPD analysis. The changes in the concentration of oxygen functional groups, caused by the catalytic reaction, were observed regardless of a reaction temperature and feed composition.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic performance of sucrose-derived CMK-3 in oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene
